comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Now then, from page 7 of the Weekly Irish Times on Saturday, 7 September 1901:
Jewish Wedding in Waterford A novel and interesting spectacle was witnessed last week when a wedding took place in one of the ante-rooms of the County Courthouse according to the rites of the Hebrew religion. The contracting parties were Mr. Myer Stein of Dublin, and Miss Ester Levin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Levin, of John street, Waterford. A large number of invitations were issued and responded to by members of the Jewish persuasion from Waterford, Dublin, and elsewhere.
Couldn't find anything in other online newspapers. However, under Fashion and Varieties in the Freeman's Journal of Friday, 30 August 1901, under "Arrivals from Scotland per Duke Line Steamer" was one Miss N.A. Stein. Then on Tuesday, 17 September 1901, again in the Freeman's Journal, we see under "Departures from Kingstown per Royal mail steamers" - R.F. Stein and Miss Stein And on Wednesday, 18 September 1901, a J.F. Stein is listed among "Departures from Kingstown per Royal Mail Steamers"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I had to look up the History of Jews in Ireland, including -
" ... There was an increase in Jewish immigration to Ireland during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. In 1871, the Jewish population of Ireland was 258; by 1881, it had risen to 453. Most of the immigration up to this time had come from England or Germany. In the wake of the Russian pogroms there was increased immigration, mostly from Eastern Europe (in particular Lithuania). By 1901, there were an estimated 3,771 Jews in Ireland, over half of them (2,200) residing in Dublin; and by 1904, the total Jewish population had reached an estimated 4,800. New synagogues and schools were established to cater for the immigrants, many of whom established shops and other businesses. ... "

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Wondering if the fellow in the middle is the Chief Rabbi of the British Empire (1891-1911), Dr Hermann Adler (1839-1911), who previously visited Waterford in 1898 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/115387482 . Biography and photo - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermann_Adler - including ...
Once he was having a lunch with British Catholic cardinal Herbert Vaughan. Cardinal asked the rabbi "Now, Dr. Adler, when may I have the pleasure of helping you to some ham?" The rabbi responded: "At Your Eminence's wedding".

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Oh wow, The original Irish Constitution of 1937 specifically gave constitutional protection to Jews. This was considered to be a necessary component to the constitution by Éamon de Valera because of the treatment of Jews elsewhere in Europe at the time. per Wikipedia

comment.author: 80456351@N00

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] La Belle, may I say that this Hat caper is an easier job than I have. Hats usually reside on the head (or nearby) whereas with my task one has to search every section of the photograph, these dogs can hide anywhere and at times I have to do with the merest glimpse of a snout or a tail, and occasionally I have had to do with evidence of certain stains on a plinth or a lamppost.
I do not want you to think that I am in any way annoyed with you in this regard, in fact I find you one of the most knowledgeable posters here and I believe you are entirely due your auspicious "Hatoriffic" Tag. 
On the other hand I am indeed disappointed with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] or "Mulier de bibliotheca, illa canum odio." as I call her. 

I do like your suggestion of "Dogtag" but this is more serious than that!!

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: Thank you for letting us know, and I now appreciate the complexity of the situation, and the loneliness of your calling. (Sound of lone dog baying in the distance.)
